awd_abstract_narration:
Cluster varieties are certain geometric spaces of parameters; certain functions of those parameters form so-called cluster algebras. These have found applications throughout mathematics and mathematical physics. This project proposes to study the geometry of cluster algebras in two senses. The first is to apply tools from algebraic geometry to the study of cluster varieties. This will hopefully enable us to understand the structure of integrals computed on cluster varieties, which are common in applications to particle physics. The second sense is to describe cluster varieties using the geometry of reflection groups. These are the symmetries formed by reflections over collections of mirrors. Such connections are already well known for finite reflection groups, but the typical cluster variety should be related to the properties of infinite reflection groups, and these are still very poorly understood.

More precisely, the first project is to compute the mixed Hodge structure on the cohomology of cluster varieties. This is joint work with Thomas Lam. In previous work, the PI and his collaborator have discovered a "curious Lefschetz symmetry" in these mixed Hodge structures. They intend to build a spectral sequence to help compute these mixed Hodge structures, and they intend to study connections between these computations, rational Catalan theory and character varieties. The second project has as its ultimate goal describing cluster fans and cluster complexes in terms of infinite Coxeter groups. Nathan Reading and the PI previously did this for cluster varieties of finite type, which corresponded to finite Coxeter groups, and partially succeeded in doing so in general. The obstacle to further progress was that they needed a lattice into which they could embed an infinite Coxeter group; in the finite case, the Coxeter group itself is such a lattice. The current project, joint with Nathan Reading and Hugh Thomas, proposes to solve this problem by using ideas from the representation theory of quivers. They also intend to find combinatorial models of these lattices, and hope to eventually find applications to cluster varieties.

por.por_cntn:
Within the last reporting period, I have:

(1) Completed revisions to my paper "Shard Modules", with Will Dana and Hugh Thomas, describing the representation theory which we expect to be key to understanding wild-type cluster algebras.

(2) Completed my paper "Affine extended weak order is a lattice" with Grant Barkley. In general, Nathan Reading and I hope to use extended weak orders to understand cluster algebras; proving that they are lattices is a key goal. The affine extended weak orders are the first nontrivial test case although, in this case, we don't expect major consequences for cluster algebras because Nathan and my papers about affine weak order are already quite thorough.

(3) Published the preprint "Cluster deep loci and mirror symmetry", with  Marco Castronovo, Mikhail Gorsky and José Simental. This paper is the first in depth study of the "deep locus" of a cluster variety, a region which is very difficult to see using the cluster tori. It establishes many lemmas about special cases, such as braid varieties and positroid varieties, and provides evidence for a string conjecture which has interested many researchers.

(4) Organized a conference on dimers in mathematical physics (together with Sebastian Franco, Rick Kenyon, Gregg Musiker and Lauren Williams, supported by DMS-1854225), a topic which has many applications to cluster algebras.

(5) Started mentoring three graduate students -- Yucong Lei, Diya Yang and Veronica Lang. Yucong is interested in working on something in the area of cluster algebras, probably tied to positroid varieties, braid varieties, or similar spaces. The other two will probably work on something related to webs and invariant theory. This topic has been tied to cluster algebras in research by Chris Fraser, Thomas Lam, Ian Le, Gregg Musiker, Kayla Wright and others, although it isn't clear yet whether Diya and Veronica's projects will be particularly close to cluster algebras.

(6) Continued and made significant progress in my research with Gregg Musiker into the combinatorics of the DP3 cluster algebra.

(7) Started a project aimed at understanding flag matroid subdivisions of permutahedra in the same way that I earlier studied matroid subdivisions of hypersimplices. Ideally, this would help us understand the cluster structure on the flag variety in the same way that my earlier work helped us understand the cluster structure on the Grassmannian.
